item.title: George Floyd death homicide, official post-mortem declares
item.description: George Floyd suffered a cardiac arrest while being restrained by police officers, the report says.

item.title: Coronavirus: Primary schools back but mixed picture on turn-out
item.description: It is the first day back for some primary pupils in England - but heads say attendance ranges between 40% and 70%.

item.title: England lockdown eases: First meeting for grandparents and new grandchild
item.description: As lockdown in England eases, Christine and David Passmore meet six-week-old Amari.

item.title: Coronavirus: Customers queue for hours as Ikea reopens 19 shops
item.description: Thousands have queued to get into the furniture giant's stores amid strict social distancing measures.

item.title: Climate change: May was sunniest calendar month on record in UK
item.description: Meteorologists say the switch from an extremely wet winter to an extremely dry spring is not "British".

item.title: New lockdown laws warning for Scotland after weekend breaches
item.description: Coronavirus guidelines could be enforced by new laws if "even a minority" continue to flout them, the first minister says.

item.title: No early return for UK tourists, says Spain
item.description: Spain's tourism minister says UK Covid-19 figures "have to improve" before tourists can come back.

item.title: George Floyd death: Liverpool players take knee in picture at Anfield
item.description: Liverpool players displayed a message of support by taking a knee around the centre circle at Anfield after the death in police custody of African-American George Floyd in Minneapolis.

item.title: Ashley Banjo: 'I looked at George Floyd and saw my dad'
item.description: Diversity's Ashley Banjo reflects on the death of George Floyd and growing up mixed race in the UK.

item.title: Grindr removes 'ethnicity filter' after complaints
item.description: The LGBT app says it has a "zero-tolerance policy for racism" and will remove the filter.

item.title: Japan launches surprise fireworks to lift spirits amid pandemic
item.description: The displays, at secret locations across Japan, were designed to lift spirits amid the pandemic.

item.title: Coventry electrician hopes to realise boyhood dream with £1m win
item.description: Simon Waddup, from Coventry, wins £1m in the Euromillions draw.

item.title: The Papers: 'Revolt' over plan to quarantine arrivals to UK
item.description: The government's plan to make travellers quarantine for 14 days features on several front pages.

item.title: George Floyd death: How black British people are reacting
item.description: Black British people react to the African-American's death, and the ongoing racial tensions in the US and UK.

item.title: Coronavirus: Seeing loved ones again
item.description: Many people have have seen family members for the first time since lockdown was enforced in the UK.

item.title: Nasa SpaceX launch: What is the Crew Dragon?
item.description: A guide to SpaceX's Crew Dragon vehicle, which carried astronauts to the space station.

item.title: Our masked identities: Cartoons of India's new normal
item.description: Cartoonist Priya Kuriyan documents how masks became prevalent in India - even before its lockdown.

item.title: How Venezuela's fuel crisis is hitting coronavirus victims
item.description: Venezuela's fuel crisis is so acute that even funeral homes are struggling to transport bodies to the cemetery.

item.title: Coronation Street to resume filming next week
item.description: The ITV soap's cameras will roll again on 9 June, 11 weeks after the cobbles fell quiet.

item.title: 'People use us to go to sleep to': Sudoku solvers become internet sensation
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of people from all over the world are watching these men solve Sudoku puzzles.

item.title: Coronavirus: The South African village preparing for Covid-19
item.description: For people in South Africa's rural areas trying to protect themselves from Covid-19, hand washing in clean water isn't possible.

item.title: UK weather in pictures: Sunny spring draws people outdoors
item.description: People flock to beaches and beauty spots to enjoy the warmer weather as some lockdown rules ease.

item.title: Candle scents inspired by pubs and other stories you may have missed
item.description: From social distancing dinner dates to candle scents inspired by pubs, here are some stories you may have missed this week.

item.title: A cluster of islands: How Shetland locked down early and stopped the virus in its tracks
item.description: Shetland was one of the UK areas worst hit by Covid-19 - now there have been no new cases for six weeks. How did they do it?

item.title: Coronavirus: Navigating the first morning at school since March
item.description: Pupils return to find their desks in rows facing forward, the windows wide open and lots of hand-sanitizer.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the future of religious worship in the UK?
item.description: Faith leaders say worshippers' flexibility during the crisis could lead to a future shift in practices.

item.title: Sunshine and eerie silence as horse racing returns
item.description: Zodiakos creates history with victory at Newcastle racecourse and Judd Trump wins at the snooker as elite sport returns to England after coronavirus.

item.title: The misleading US protest posts you should ignore
item.description: Protests after the death of George Floyd have led to a surge in misleading videos and unfounded theories.

item.title: Obituary: Christo Javacheff, the artist who wrapped the world
item.description: The artist known as Christo was famous for wrapping huge buildings and entire coastlines in fabric.

item.title: Dancing On My Own: The story behind Robyn's 2010 'sad banger'
item.description: The Swedish singer discusses her pop classic, and how she once became 'tired of the broken heart'.

item.title: George Floyd: Anonymous hackers re-emerge amid US unrest
item.description: As the US is engulfed in civil unrest, the masked hackers are being credited with new action.

item.title: Coronavirus changes how doctors deal with death
item.description: Five doctors administering end-of-life care reflect on the current crisis.

item.title: Remote working: How cities might change if we worked from home more
item.description: Our homes, transport and city-centre spaces would change if we worked from home for good.

item.title: Libya conflict: Russia and Turkey risk Syria repeat
item.description: Gen Haftar's forces have been beaten back from Tripoli but that does not mean peace is at hand.

item.title: George Floyd death: Why do some protests turn violent?
item.description: In the US, peaceful protests over police violence have escalated into widespread riots and looting.

item.title: Carly Fiorina's journey from secretary to CEO
item.description: The US entrepreneur started her business career answering the phone, and went on to lead Hewlett-Packard.

item.title: In mid-Pacific with nowhere to land
item.description: A group of performers were halfway across the ocean in a 75ft boat when the pandemic erupted - leaving them with nowhere to go.

item.title: England's Plunkett open to playing for USA
item.description: England fast bowler Liam Plunkett says he would be open to playing for the United States in the future.

item.title: Zidane, Rooney, Bale, Gascoigne - how to watch BBC Sport's Euros Rewind this summer
item.description: Follow BBC Sport Euros Rewind this summer and relive classic matches from European Championships across BBC TV, BBC iPlayer, the BBC Sport website and mobile app.

item.title: Tuesday's gossip - Chelsea consider joining race for Werner
item.description: Messi to stay at Barca after clause expires, Real reject deal to sign Willian, Chelsea consider Werner move, plus more.

item.title: Striker Taylor will not play for Charlton when season resumes, says boss Bowyer
item.description: Charlton's top scorer Lyle Taylor will not play when the season resumes because he does not want to risk getting injured, boss Lee Bowyer says.

item.title: Lewandowski scores twice to equal scoring record
item.description: Robert Lewandowski scores twice in Bayern Munich's 5-0 win over Fortuna Dusseldorf to equal his most prolific season

item.title: Carl Frampton set to fight at 'end of July or start of August' - but not against Jamel Herring
item.description: Carl Frampton says he has been told to get ready for a fight "at the end of July or start of August", but not against Jamel Herring.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are social distancing and self-isolation rules?
item.description: You can now meet more people and play certain non-contact sports in the UK - but what are they?

item.title: Coronavirus: Which schools are reopening for pupils?
item.description: Which children will be the first to go back to school, and what about the rest?

item.title: Coronavirus: When will shops open and what will the rules be?
item.description: Non-essential shops can reopen in England in June, but will I be able to buy a book or have a haircut?

item.title: Hay fever v coronavirus: what are the symptoms?
item.description: The Royal College of General Practitioners is warning people not to mix up the symptoms.

item.title: Social distancing: A practical guide to how to socialise now
item.description: Meeting friends? Here's how to handle the awkward new rules - from sharing food to avoiding hugs.

item.title: Coronavirus': Parents shamed for back-to-school choices
item.description: Parents of year six and year one pupils have been falling out over whether to send them back to school.

item.title: Coronavirus: We answer kids' questions about going back to school
item.description: The BBC's Education Editor Branwen Jeffreys answers kids' questions about going back to school.

item.title: Coronavirus: School return plan 'like a jigsaw puzzle'
item.description: A head teacher explains how she is piecing school life back together before children return.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the risks for children?
item.description: Children seem to be at low risk from the disease, but can they still spread it?

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should be shielding?
item.description: People most at risk of needing hospital treatment if they get coronavirus are being asked to stay home.

item.title: Coronavirus: Are these targets being hit?
item.description: Ministers have set targets for testing, medical equipment and hospital beds. Have they delivered?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules on weddings?
item.description: There is a lot of uncertainty around when and how weddings are allowed to take place. What are your rights?

item.title: Coronavirus: What tests are being done in the UK?
item.description: What are the tests for coronavirus, who are they for and how do they work?

item.title: Will I still get paid if I have to self-isolate? And other questions
item.description: Will employees still get paid if they are told to self-isolate? And other questions answered by BBC experts.

item.title: All you need to know about new measures
item.description: How will social and work life be different after the easing of some restrictions around the UK?

item.title: Coronavirus: How safe is it to get on a plane?
item.description: Many airlines are planning to resume flying, but they first need to reduce the risks of Covid-19.

item.title: Coronavirus: What does it mean if I've been furloughed by work?
item.description: Millions unable to do their job due to coronavirus will have their wages paid by a new scheme.

item.title: Coronavirus: What help are self-employed getting from government?
item.description: What is being done for the five million self-employed people in the UK facing a sudden loss of income?

item.title: Coronavirus: Dental practices to reopen from 8 June
item.description: Dental practices in England have been told they can reopen from Monday, 8 June.

item.title: Dominic Cummings: Fact-checking the row
item.description: Senior Conservatives are still questioning adviser's account of driving his family 260 miles during lockdown.

item.title: Coronavirus: How will contact tracing work in England?
item.description: Millions in the UK will soon be asked to monitor who they have been near to combat coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus: What can you do in Scotland from Friday?
item.description: After almost 10 weeks of lockdown which restrictions are being eased - and which remain in force?

item.title: Dominic Cummings: Did he break lockdown rules?
item.description: The UK PM's most senior adviser has responded to accusations that he broke lockdown rules - what did he say?

item.title: Coronavirus: The mystery of asymptomatic 'silent spreaders'
item.description: Scientists have discovered more evidence about a strange and worrying feature of the coronavirus
